Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Solid-State Frameworks: Design and Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the design and synthesis of zeolite-like frameworks based on assembly of Archimedean polyhedra constructed from hydrogen-bonded molecular tiles and related molecular frameworks to create a new family of microporous molecular frameworks with structures and properties that can be modified through choice of molecular constituents. These frameworks are used as scaffolds that encapsulate functional molecules such as laser dyes as well as templates for synthesis of nanoreticulated metal oxides that replicate the topology of the zeolite-like frameworks. This work also capitalizes on the unique ability of lamellar GS compounds to form high quality thin films with controlled two-dimensional packing of conjugated guest molecules with adjustable electronic properties for a systematic examination of electron transport in a field effect transistor configuration.

The motivation for this project is driven by promise of new materials that capitalize on the versatility of organic synthesis, which permit manipulation of properties through molecular design. The project explores the synthesis of materials for a new generation of solid-state lasers as well as the molding of nanomaterials with unique electronic properties that can impact technologies ranging from displays to solar energy. The project also provides summer research experiences for undergraduates and faculty from minority-serving and four-year institutions, research experiences for high school students, exposure of students and postdocs to the industrial section through the NYU University Chapter of the Chemists' Club, and professional development opportunities for students and postdocs that will prepare them for careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research on the design of new organic solid-state materials based on molecular building blocks that assemble into crystalline frameworks that encapsulate guest molecules, to form so-called inclusion compounds. Outcomes of this project include the discovery of a unique hydrogen-bonded framework consisting of molecular tiles assembled into polyhedral cages that embed laser dye molecules, suggesting a pathway toward the design of versatile organic solid state laser materials. Other discoveries include hydrogen bonded frameworks in which moleculear guests can exchange dynamically with other molecules through unique pathways that range from a peristaltic motion of flexible channels to microscopic lamellae that enhance transport of guest molecules in and out of the crystal. This discoveries reveal new routes to post-synthetic modification of inclusion compounds, wherein functional guests can be introduced that otherwise were not amenable to encapsulation during the initial crystallization of the framework. During the later stage of the award, preliminary results were obtained that promise a new approach for determining the molecular structure of compounds of interest to the organic synthetic community as well as the pharmaceutical sector. This approach involves trapping large molecules, some with multiple chiral centers, in the hydrogen-bonded frameworks in a single step crystallization, enabling subsequent determination of their molecular structure using single crystal X-ray diffraction, the gold standard for molecular structure determination. Work on this topic is in progress.

During the award period, the project also included several activities aimed at broadening its impact on STEM education and the development of emerging talent, including  (i) supervision of summer research experiences for undergraduates and faculty from minority-serving and four-year institutions; (ii) research mentoring of high school students from underrepresented groups; (iii) coordination and oversight of the University Chapter of the Chemists’ Club, which provides undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs with direct exposure to the industrial sector and increases their awareness of career opportunities; (iv) development of undergraduate and graduate programs at the newly established NYU campuses in Abu Dhabi and Shanghai, including student exchanges and summer research experiences in the PI laboratory.
